Review Paper Catalytic strategies for the direct transformation of biomass-derived glucose into levulinate esters: A brief review Shuolin Zhou Writing – review & editing Investigation Conceptualization a Xianxiang Liu Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition Conceptualization b ⁎ a Changsha Normal University, Changsha 410100, China Changsha Normal University Changsha 410100 China aChangsha Normal University, Changsha 410100, China b National & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources, Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province, Hunan Normal University, Changsha 410081, China National & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province Hunan Normal University Changsha 410081 China bNational & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources, Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province, Hunan Normal University, Changsha 410081, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Biomass resource has attracted extensive attention owing to abundance and potential for producing various high value-added chemicals and biofuels. Levulinate ester (LEs) are considered as one of the most attractive and potential energy compounds due to their excellent fuel additive/blending properties, as well as their broad applications in our daily life. LEs can be efficiently synthesized through the catalytic valorization of biomass-derived glucose via alcoholysis reactions. This review provides an overview of the most recent and promising advances in the one-pot production of LEs from glucose in the presence of acid catalysts. The plausible catalytic routes for preparation of LEs from glucose are analyzed. The development of different homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts used in this process is reviewed and compared. In this review, the combination of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in an appropriate ratio is promising for effectively converting glucose into LEs. Moreover, future prospects, including opportunities and current challenges for the sustainable production of LEs from glucose, also be emphasized. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Biomass Levulinate esters Catalytic conversion Glucose One-pot Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Fossil fuels, an important non-renewable carbon resource, supplies most of the fuels, chemicals, and materials essential to modern society. The use of fossil fuels is increasing along with the increase in human population, which is projected to be around 9 billion by 2050 [1]. However, the continuous consumption of fossil energy, oil price fluctuations, environmental issues, and other related issues arising from its use will lead to a series of challenges in the long term. Therefore, the transition of human society from the petrochemical industry towards the renewable chemicals industry is very important for sustainable development, and the space of this transition is gradually accelerating [2,3]. Biomass is the largest renewable carbon resource on earth, with a global annual output of at least about 180 billion tons [4,5]. Biomass, including cellulose (40-50 %), lignin (15-30 %), and hemicellulose (20-30 %) [6], has the potential to serve as an alternative source for producing various functional materials, chemicals and biofuels [7–12], which has attracted increasing attention. The demand for the biomass-based products has been growing year by year. The utilization of biomass resources, which urgently needs to shift from low-efficiency energy sources such as direct incineration to high-efficiency and comprehensive utilization, has become a hot research area. Levulinate esters (LEs), which contain a carbonyl and an ester group in their molecular structure, are among the most potential biomass compounds due to their good physico-chemical properties. For examples, important fine chemicals products such as γ-valerolactone [13–18], N-substituted pyrrolidinones [19,20], 1,4-pentanediol [21], ketals [22], alkoxypentanoates [23], methyl vinyl ketone [24], and other important chemical products can be further synthesized (Fig. 1 ). LEs, which are liquid-phase compounds, are deemed as green solvents due to their lower vapor pressures compared with conventional solvents, which allows their use in metallic surface degreasing processes as an alternative to chlorinated solvents [25]. Moreover, the unique physical and chemical properties of LEs make them widely used in other fields, such as surfactants, medical drugs, plasticizers, fragrances, coatings, adhesives, detergents, flavoring agents, polymer precursors, and biological lubricants [26]. In recent years, various LEs, especially short-chain esters such as methyl levulinate (ML), ethyl levulinate (EL), propyl levulinate (PL), and butyl levulinate (BL), have been gaining special attention owing to their potential as oxygenated biorenewable fuels [27]. Moreover, some published reviews focus on the catalytic production of ML [28], EL [29,30], and BL [31]. The energy density of short-chain LEs is closed to the energy density of gasoline and higher than ethanol [32]. For example, the boiling point of EL and longer chain levulinate have similar boiling points to the heavy gasoline compounds or middle diesel fuel boiling ranges [33]. Both ML and EL exhibit superior anti-knock compared to the reference Euro95 gasoline, as they readily produce stable intermediates during the auto-ignition process [34]. It was reported that engine power and torque with fuel blends (containing additional of EL were generally similar to those with diesel (<3 % differences), whereas brake specific fuel and energy consumption were lower with the fuel blends than with diesel, which suggests higher fuel conversion efficiencies for the fuel blends [35]. In addition, LEs as blending components in fuel have several advantages, such as high flashpoint and lubricity, good fluidity, and improved viscosity and density. These properties make them suitable as a performance regulator for gasoline, biodiesel and other transportation mixed fuels [36,37]. It was worth noting that the BL’s blending amount can be further increased up to 35 mol % by modifying its aromatic content. LEs, in particular ML, EL and BL, have higher engine performance, longer life, and lower CO and NOx emissions [27,38–41]. To date, several typical pathways for synthesizing LEs have been developed in organic synthesis, as shown in Fig. 2 . For example, LEs can be synthesized directly via the esterification reaction of biomass-derived compounds levulinic acid (LA) under mild conditions is highly attractive [42–47]. Alcoholysis of 5-(halomethyl)furfural (X = Cl, Br) [48,49], furfuryl alcohol [50–58] or α-angelica lactone [59–63], to generate LEs compounds are the available routes. Additionally, furfural is a promising platform compound derived from lignocellulosic biomass [64], and the one-pot conversion of furfural to EL has also been developed [65]. However, it is particularly noteworthy that some reaction substrates are obtained from biomass through complicated production process, difficult separation and purification process and high cost, which greatly limits the practical application. The direct synthesis of LEs from raw biomass represents a pivotal strategy for sustainable chemistry, as it capitalizes on renewable feedstocks to minimize costs while creating high-value products from waste. A lot of raw biomass such as wheat straw [66,67], bamboo [4,68], sugarcane bagasse [69,70], oil palm trunk [71], corn stover [72–74], cassava [75], rice husks [76], wood [77,78] and so on, have been widely adopted as starting feedstocks for synthesis of LEs. In fact, direct conversion of actual biomass with complex structures results in low or moderate LEs yields due to a combination of solubility issues and the drastic conditions required for the catalytic process [79]. Additionally, a lot of by-products formation and complex product separation significantly increase the process cost. Carbohydrates are important derivative products of lignocellulosic biomass, with advantages such as extensive sources and abundant reserves [80,81]. LEs obtained directly starting from simple carbohydrates such as glucose via alcoholysis are highly convenient [82–84]. Cellulose, used as a substrate, faces several challenges in the catalytic process, including dissolution, the formation of by-products (e.g., humins), and the separation of products and catalyst, which remain significant hurdles [85]. Although fructose is more likely to be converted to LEs than glucose, it is less abundant and more expensive than glucose. Glucose, as a typical C6 sugar, is cheap and is a readily available renewable resource on a large scale, which is considered to be an ideal starting substrate for the production of premium chemicals and clean energy [86]. The production of alkyl levulinates from glucose via one-pot cascade strategies offers significant advantages in terms of process economics, such as reduced reaction time, energy costs, and solvent consumption, as well as waste minimization. This current work is aimed at carrying out a comprehensive analysis of various types of catalysts (homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts) used for LEs production from glucose. It is hoped to provide some feasible schemes for efficient and economical catalytic systems for the direct production of LEs from glucose. 2 The reaction pathways for glucose conversion to LEs The direct transformation of glucose into LEs via alcoholysis is not a single-step reaction but a sophisticated cascade process, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . It is widely recognized that two classic reaction pathways have been proposed. In Pathway I, glucose first isomerizes to fructose catalyzed by Lewis acids. The fructose then dehydrates to form 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), which subsequently undergoes alcoholysis catalyzed by Brønsted acids to yield 5-alkoxymethylfurfural (AMF). Finally, AMF undergoes a ring-opening reaction to form LEs. In contrast, Pathway II begins with the Brønsted acid-catalyzed Fischer glycosidation of glucose, producing alkyl glucoside. This intermediate is then sequentially decomposed into AMF and LEs. Meanwhile, it is worth noting that the presence of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites in a catalyst introduces complexity, whereby the Lewis acid-catalyzed isomerization of alkyl glucoside to alkyl fructoside can occur concurrently with its Brønsted acid-catalyzed formation from fructose [87,88]. Consequently, the combination of Brønsted and Lewis acids exerts a synergistic effect, leading to significantly enhanced reaction efficiency. Other possible mechanistic pathway, such as glucose conversion to EL through 1,6-anhydro-β-D-glucopyranose (LG) and levoglucosone (LGO), was also proposed [89]. Although the mechanistic pathways remain contentious, it is crucial to emphasize that they produce assorted various by-products and humins, whose formation not only triggers side reactions but also deactivates the catalyst, thereby compromising process efficiency. More significantly, the reaction pathways for the production of LEs from glucose are believed to depend primarily on the reaction conditions, particularly the catalyst, solvent, and reaction temperature. Therefore, a deep understanding of this intricate reaction network is crucial for designing more efficient and selective catalytic systems. 3 Various catalysts for the conversion of glucose into LEs 3.1 Inorganic acid catalyst Inorganic acid catalysts are both abundant and highly effective across a broad range of acid-catalyzed reactions, as their protons can be uniformly dispersed, especially in aqueous media. Moreover, mineral acids demonstrate exceptional thermal stability under most acid-catalyzed reaction conditions, and their acid strength can be readily tuned simply by adjusting the water content. For example, Zhang et al. used H3PO4 (a weak Brønsted acid) as catalyst for the transformation of glucose, resulting in a particularly low EL yield (3.5 mol %)(Table 1 entry 1) [90]. That was probably because the isomerization of glucose to fructose is mainly catalyzed by Lewis acids. HCl used as catalyst also obtained the low ML yield (Table 1 entry 2) from glucose [91]. Bernardo et al. reported that 10 % mol HReO4 was reacted at 160 °C for 6 h, the yield of EL was 27 % (Table 1 entry 3) used glucose as raw substrate [92]. Notably, the yield of EL increases progressively with reaction time, reaching 80 % (Table 1 entry 4) after 72 h. A lot of work have employed sulfuric acid as the catalyst to catalyze the conversion of glucose into LEs, obtaining LEs yields of 13 to 50 % (Table 1 entries 5-17) [93–96]. Peng et al. [97] demonstrated that in a methanol medium containing low concentrations of H2SO4 (≤ 0.01mol/L), approximately 50 mol % of the initial glucose (Table 1 entry 8) was converted into ML, following a first-order kinetic model. A plausible reaction pathway for the low H2SO4 acid-catalyzed conversion of glucose in methanol medium was proposed (Fig. 4 ). In the initial step, glycosidic hydroxyl of glucose reacted with methanol via a condensation reaction catalyzed by acid catalyst, forming methyl glucosides, which is dehydrated to 5-methoxymethylfurfural (MMF). The carbonyl group of MMF can further be converted into an acetal group in 2-(dimethoxymethyl)-5-(methoxymethyl)furan. These intermediate products are converted in a serial mode to ML through sequential hydrolysis and methanol addition. Another parallel route is that glucose is first decomposed to HMF, which can then be converted either in a serial mode to levulinic acid (LA) and formic acid, or to 5-methoxymethylfurfural (MMF) by etherification with methanol. Zhu et al. [96] also investigated the kinetics for production of EL from glucose in ethanol medium using extremely low sulfuric acid as the catalyst, achieving 44.8 % ML yield (Table 1 entry 9). The results suggested that the kinetics follow a simplified first-order kinetic model. Very recently, Xu’s groups [94] applied ultralow concentration sulfuric acid for the conversion of glucose, achieving the maximum EL yield of 45.2 % (Table 1 entry 10) at 210 °C with 0.5 h. Based on the combing DFT theoretical calculations and experimental results, EL is more likely to be generated via 5-ethoxymethylfurfural (EMF) rather than LA. The heating method employed can influence glucose conversion. Xiao et al. compared the effects of microwave dielectric heating and conventional external heating on the methanolysis of glucose, using H2SO4 as the catalyst [98]. Under otherwise identical moderate conditions, microwave dielectric heating gave an ML yield (53.9 %) roughly three times higher than that obtained with conventional external heating at 160 °C (Table 1 entries 11-12). The co-solvent effect played an essential role in the multi-step reaction of glucose conversion. Xu et al. [99] compared the one-pot conversion of glucose in ethanol and ethanol/n-hexane medium and found that the yield of EL plummeted in the ethanol/n-hexane system using extremely low acid, affording only 0.7 % EL (Table 1 entries 13-14). Very recently, Xu and collaborators [89] mentioned the EL yield obtained in the ethanol/THF system was lower than that of the ethanol system by extremely low Brønsted acid (H2SO4) using high concentration glucose as raw material (Table 1 entries 15-16). Although the addition of THF can enhance glucose conversion at lower temperatures, it offers no clear benefit for either the isomerization of glucose to fructose or the subsequent formation of EL. On the other hand, at higher temperature, the addition of THF reduces the concentration of ethanol in the system, proved by molecular dynamics (MD) simulations on the solvent distribution, thus resulting in a decrease in EL yield. Xu and collaborators confirmed the addition of THF in ethanol is beneficial for the ethyl glucoside (EDGP) formation from high concentration glucose catalyzed by extremely low Brønsted acid (H2SO4), decreasing the energy barrier of glucose degradation. Most significantly, the plausible glucose alcoholysis pathways in this study were proposed according to the reaction temperature (Fig. 5 ). Especially, the main reaction pathways for high-concentration glucose under high-temperature conditions: (i) glucose conversion to EL through LG and LGO; (ii) glucose conversion to EL through fructose, HMF, EMF, and EL; and (iii) glucose conversion to humins. It is noteworthy that inorganic acid, especially sulfuric acid (H2SO4) with Brønsted acids, have been extensively studied and can achieve good yields (up to ∼50 % in some cases) of LEs from glucose. Nevertheless, their inability to be recovered and reused, coupled with their corrosive properties, presents significant obstacles for industrial-scale applications. 3.2 Metal salt catalysts Metal salt catalysts with Lewis acid sites are simple, cheap, and readily available, and have been widely employed for the one-pot catalytic conversion of glucose into LEs. AlCl3, used a typical Lewis acid catalyst, has been employed in LEs production via a one-pot process, and only yields of 18 % ML (Table 2 , entry 1) and 30 % EL (Table 2, entry 2) were obtained, respectively [90,91]. One possible reason could be lack of high strong acidity for conversion of glucose, which results in less dehydration of the reactants and thus hinders further conversion [100]. It was demonstrated that the EL yield was greatly improved when the combined use of AlCl3 and H3PO4 as catalysts was employed, giving about 50 % EL yield (Table 2, entry 3) at 200 °C for 6 h [90]. Various sulfates metal salts have been investigated as Lewis acid catalysts for the conversion of glucose to LEs. Feng et al. used Al2(SO4)3 catalyst for the synthesis of EL from glucose [101]. Under the conditions of 180 °C for 2 h, 82.42 % of glucose was convert, affording an EL yield of 18.28 % (Table 2, entry 4). Similarly, Xu et al. reported that the 23 % yield of ML (Table 2, entry 5) was obtained from glucose over Al2(SO4)3 at 200 °C for 4 h [102]. Peng’s research group recently reported that using Al2(SO4)3 as catalyst and ethylene glycol as co-solvent in the reaction system can enhance the selectivity of LEs compared with reactions in single monohydric alcohols such as methanol, ethanol, giving an unprecedented yield (56 %) (Table 2, entry 6) of EL from an initial glucose concentration of 200 g/L [103]. The authors demonstrated that ethylene glycol not only served as a solubilizer of glucose in ethanol to improve reactivity, but also acted as a supporter to inhibit the polymerization of furan compounds, thereby offering high chemoselectivity in glucose conversion. The effect of glucose concentration on glucose conversion was investigated using the low concentration of Al2(SO4)3 [104]. It was observed that the increasing the glucose concentration from 20 to 200 g/L, decreased the yield of EL from 47 % to 27 % (Table 2, entries 7-8), while significantly boosting the formation of water-soluble oligomers (WSO). Zhou et al. [91] reported that Al2(SO4)3 can effectively catalytic conversion of concentrated sugars into LEs. The 64 % yield of ML (Table 2, entry 9) was given at 160 °C for 2.5 h from glucose, and the catalyst can be reused for five runs. It was noted that the ML yield (Table 2, entries 9-12) was increased when Al2(SO4)3 and H2SO4 were added to the reaction system [91,105]. Particularly, a moderate yield of ML (46.48 %) (Table 2, entry 13) and a yield of LA of 24.2 % could also be achieved from glucose using Al2(SO4)3 and H2SO4 as mixed catalyst in a methanol/water solvent system [105]. Similarly, Feng et al. also measured the yield of EL was increased to 45.4 % (Table 2, entry 14) with the introduction of Al2(SO4)3 and Amberlyst 15, which higher than that of Al2(SO4)3 and Amberlyst 15 alone [101]. The synergistic Brønsted and Lewis acid sites can promote the efficient transformation of glucose into EL. Various other metal sulfates, such as SnSO4, Fe2(SO4)3, MnSO4, were evaluated for conversion of glucose to ML, and the low ML yield (0-15 %) (Table 2, entries 15-24) was obtained [91,106]. However, An et al. [107] found that Fe2(SO4)3 was considered as an efficient catalyst for the conversion of glucose; a 39.6 mol % yield of BL (Table 2, entry 25) was obtained at 160 °C within 3 h. Moreover, the catalytic performance of Fe2(SO4)3 better than that of SO4 2-/SnO2 and SO4 2-/Fe2O3-SnO2 under the same conditions. Sun et al. [106] assessed the synthesis of ML, EL and IL over Fe2(SO4)3 catalyst in methanol, ethanol and isopropanol, and the corresponding yield was 26.4 %, 39 % and 54.8 %, respectively (Table 2, entries 26-28). The yields of ML and EL from glucose in pure alcohols over La2(SO4)3 were comparable, at 29.1 % and 29.9 % (Table 2, entries 29-30), respectively. Metal triflates are a kind of typical Lewis acid and are widely used in organic synthesis reactions. Interestingly, Kumar et al. [108] performed the glucose conversion over La(OTf)3·H2O catalyst under aqueous-methanol (5:1) solvent system. ML was obtained with 74 % yield (Table 2, entry 31), working within 2 h at 160 °C. Tominaga et al. proved that In(OTf)3 used as Lewis acid can effective for the formation of ML using glucose as the substrate (Table 2, entry 32). Moreover, during the In(OTf)3-catalyzed reaction of glucose process the intermediate 5-methoxymethylfurfural was observed [109]. A series of metal triflates for one-pot conversion of glucose into LEs was systematically investigated by Bodachivskyi et al. [110,111]. The authors [110] reported that strong Lewis acids (e.g., In(OTf)3, Al(OTf)3, Hf(OTf)4, and Sn(OTf)2), which exhibited enhanced Brønsted acidity in protic solvents such as water and methanol, can efficiently convert glucose into ML via an initial Lewis-acid-catalyzed isomerization step (Table 2, entries 33-38). More the possible reaction pathways of converting glucose into platform molecules in water and methanol was proposed and is illustrated in Fig. 6 . ML is formed by Lewis acid-catalyzed isomerization of glucose into fructose followed by (Lewis acid-assisted) Brønsted acid-catalyzed dehydration/rehydration processes. Compared to La(OTf)3 and Y(OTf)3 (Table 2, entries 39-41), both Al(OTf)3 and Sn(OTf)2 were preferentially promote dehydration/rehydration processes of the glucose towards EL, giving 67 % and 53 % EL yield at 140 °C for 4 h, respectively [111]. Meanwhile, the authors observed that both NaOTf and AgOTf were almost inactive towards glucose, giving only little conversion therefore into EL (Table 2, entries 42–43) [111]. Chowdhury et al. [112] demonstrated that mesoporous α-Ti(HPO4)2·H2O nanomaterial can be used to catalytically convert glucose to LA and then LA to LEs in the presence of various alcohols, and a high product yield (up to 98 %) and a TOF value of up to 43.00 h−1 were achieved. At the same time, a satisfactory ML yield of 80 % (Table 2, entry 44) was also obtained via one-pot process using glucose as raw material at 120 °C for 8 h. In summary, metal salt catalysts, particularly those featuring Lewis acid sites (e.g., AlCl3, Al2(SO4)3, Fe2(SO4)3), offer notable advantages including simplicity, low cost, and wide availability. Furthermore, their Lewis acidity facilitates key steps such as glucose isomerization to fructose, and when combined with Brønsted acids (e.g., H2SO4, Amberlyst 15), they exhibit synergistic effects that significantly enhance LEs yields, achieving up to 50–67 % under optimized conditions. Metal triflates, especially those based on rare or precious metals, face obstacles such as high cost, difficult recovery, and sensitivity to reaction conditions, which hinder their scalable application. 3.3 Ionic liquids catalyst Ionic liquids (ILs) are thermally stable, non-volatile, non-flammable and reusable, and their reactivity rivals that of homogeneous catalysts. At the same time, ILs are also considered a new class of green solvent and have attracted considerable attention as potentially highly efficient catalytic systems for biomass conversion. Gomes et al. performed transformation of glucose into EL using taurine hydrogen sulfate, [Tur][HSO4], achieving an EL yield of 53 % (Table 3 , entry 1) at 180 °C for 2 h [113]. However, the high catalyst dosage of 100 mol % was used. Saravanamurugan et al. [114] compared different sulfonic acid-functionalized ionic liquids (SO3H-ILs) as catalysts for the catalytic transformation of glucose into LEs (Table 3, entries 2-7). However, only 6 % to 13 % yields of EL were achieved with 94 % conversion of glucose. It was clearly suggested that glucose was preferentially converted glucose to EDGP rather than isomerized to fructose when using glucose as raw material under strong Brønsted acidic conditions, resulting in EDGP yields of 50 % to 62 %. Another acidic ionic liquid catalyst, [SMIM][FeCl4], which contains both Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites, was used for the conversion of glucose to EL [115]. It was obviously demonstrated that the EL yield produced from a one-step reaction was lower than that from a two step process, in which glucose was firstly converted to LA and then to EL production (Table 3, entries 8-9). Song and co-workers [116] developed heteropolyanion-based ionic liquid (IL-POM) catalysts with tunable acidity. Among various IL-POM, the optimum [PyPS]3PW12O40 [PyPS=1-(3-sulfopropyl) pyridinium] catalyst was selected and studied for ML production for glucose, and a 58.7 % yield of ML (Table 3, entry 10) was achieved at 170 °C for 4 h. Based on the aforementioned studies, ILs show great potential not only as novel catalysts but also as solvents in the process of glucose conversion. Despite the excellent reusability of ionic liquid catalysts such as [PyPS]3PW12O40, which allows for simple recovery via temperature-controlled separation and reduces operational costs, their widespread adoption is hindered by several inherent drawbacks. The complex production processes, high synthesis costs, and non-negligible toxicity associated with various ILs present considerable challenges for one-pot catalytic applications. 3.4 Heteropolyacid catalyst Heteropolyacid (HPA) catalysts exhibit potential advantages in a rang of catalytic reactions owing to their strong Brønsted acidity, tunable structure, and ability to form pseudoliquid phase in polar solvents that mimics homogeneous catalysis. Zhang et al. [117] tested the pure Brønsted acid H3PW12O40 (HPW) for catalyzing for alcoholysis of glucose into EL. Only a 25.3 % EL yield (Table 4 , entry 1) was provided, because the reaction mainly stopped at the methyl glucosides step despite almost glucose full conversion. Chen et al. [118] also mentioned the use of [3·2H]3[PW12O40]2 to convert glucose to EL production, and it showed a low EL yield (20 %) when the reaction temperature was improved to 150 °C after 24 h (Table 4, entries 2-3). However, HPA often readily dissolve in polar solvents, which complicates their separation and reuse. In addition, their bulk forms exhibit extremely low BET surface areas (< 5 m² g-¹), severely limiting access of reactants to the catalytic active sites. Supported heteropoly acids have been fabricated and have attracted increasing attention because they can be readily separated and recycled from the reaction system. Zhao et al. [119] prepared a series of supported phosphotungstic acid catalyst using an impregnation method. It was found that HPW/H-ZSM-5 showed the highest catalytic activity for production of EL from fructose, whereas the yield of 19.1 % EL (Table 4, entry 4) was obtained using glucose as raw material over 20 wt. % HPW/H-ZSM-5 catalyst. Lai et al. [87] synthesized a series of metal/Si-pillared montmorillonite supported phosphotungstic acid catalysts (SG-HPW-XSiMt-y, where X = La3+, Ce3+, Er3+, Cu2+, Al3+, Ti4+, Zr4+) via sol-gel method. It was worth noting that the SG-HPW-SiMt-20 catalyst, with strong Brønsted acidity and negligible Lewis acidity, gave merely 21.6 % ML yield (Table 4, entry 5) without formation of methyl lactate (MLA), due to the lack of heteroatoms-incorporation. Reaction pathways for glucose conversion to ML was proposed and is shown in Fig. 7 . The conversion process includes the steps: glucose→fructose→MMF→ML and glucose→methyl glucoside (MG) →methyl fructoside→MMF→ML, and the conversion efficiency for each step is actually associated with the acid type. Among theses catalysts, SG-HPW-ZrSiMt-20 showed the satisfactory performance for conversion of glucose with high ML yield (65.8 %) (Table 4, entry 6) at 170 °C for 4 h. Lai et al. [120] also designed the multifunctional catalyst (DPW-CeSiM) using Ce–Si pillared montmorillonite (CeSiM) clay heterostructures, incorporated with Wells-Dawson tungstophosphoric acid (H6P2W18O64, DPW), obtaining EL at 170 °C for 4 h with 56.2 % yield (Table 4, entry 7) and nearly 100 % conversion of glucose. They claimed that the combination of the porous structure and dual acid able to impart synergistic effect for efficiently catalyzed the conversion of glucose into EL. Furthermore, the DPW-CeSiM catalyst showed excellent stability, with no significant change in the glucose conversion and EL yield after six cycle. Notably, replacing the H+ of HPW with metal cations not only tunes its acidity but also yields a series of insoluble solid acid catalysts. Liu et al. [121] reported that Fe3+-modified HPW catalyst, Fe-HPW-1, could adjust the acidity of HPW and introduce additional Lewis acidity sites into the catalyst. However, an EL yield of 13.8 % (Table 4, entry 8) was obtained when using glucose as substrate, which was markedly lower than that from fructose, suggesting that Fe-HPW-1 catalyst did not facilitate the required isomerization of glucose to fructose to form ML. In a similar manner, Zhao et al. [122] prepared the K-HPW-1 catalyst by modifing HPW with K+ for the synthesis of EL. The results showed that the yield of EL was only14.5 % (Table 4, entry 9) when glucose was reacted at 150 °C for 2 h. Jagannivasan et al. [123] reported that phosphovanadotungstic acid (HPVW) used as catalyst for synthesis of EL from glucose in a stainless-steel autoclave, with an EL yield of 34 % (Table 4, entry 10) was obtained at 180 °C after 2 h. As a further improvement of HPA-based catalysis, Very recently, Jagannivasan et al. [88] further prepared tailored HPAs by replacing tungsten (W) in phosphotungstic acid with vanadium (V), named HPV1W. It was found that the EL yield was escalated from 36 to 82 % when the glucose concentration increased from 30 to 50 g/L using 27 wt % of catalyst (Table 4, entries 11-12). They measured that the pH level of the reactant feed was to be 2 for a glucose concentration of 50 g/L, while at 18 g/L concentration, the pH monitored was 6, which was the main reason for the formation of EL with high yield at higher glucose concentrations. The HPVW catalyst with a suitable combination of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites favored the formation of EL, and the plausible catalytic pathway initiated through the intermediate formation of glucosides and fructosides may be presumed to proceed with the ethanolysis of EMF to yield EL was proposed (Fig. 8 ). Zhang et al. [117] screened a series of double acids HPWM catalyst (M represented Lewis acid metal, M=Ti, Zr, Zn) for alcoholysis of glucose to EL. The results showed that HPWTi, which contains certain Lewis acidity and moderate B/L acid ratio, was considered as the most efficient catalyst. Under conditions of 130 °C for 4 h, HPWTi afforded the highest ML yield (62.4 %) (Table 4, entry 13), outperforming HPWZn and HPWFe with lower or higher B/L acid ratio. Interestingly, 95.4 % glucose conversion and 65.7 % ML yield (Table 4, entry 14) were obtained when the reaction system added to an extra of 5 wt % water. The authors proposed that the additional of water could firstly promotes Lewis acid catalyzed isomerization of glucose to fructose, thereby enhancing the glucose conversion, while simultaneously preventing the formation of MG. Titanium containing heteropoly tungstate catalysts was developed for synthesis of LEs, and 100 % conversion of glucose and 21 % yield of EL (Table 4, entry 15) was obtained over Ti0.75TPA catalyst at 120 °C for 6 h [124]. Zhang et al. [125] discovered that aluminum phosphotungstate (AlPW) with Brønsted and Lewis acidic processed superior activity for the transformation of glucose to EL, supplying 62.9 % yield of ML (Table 4, entry 16) at 150 °C within 0.5 h when using traditional heating method with the extremely low methanol-to-glucose ratio. Moreover, AlPW can act as a bulk-type catalyst, absorb the polar reactants in a reaction system, which may contributed to high activity of the catalyst. Interestingly, the author also found that the ML yield obtained using traditional heating method was closed to that of yield obtained with microwaves (Table 4, entry 17), which showed favorable industrial application potential. Recently, Zhang et al. [126] further reported that a representative bifunctional catalyst (aluminum phosphotungstate, AlPW) and its Brønsted acid form (HPW) was used for catalytic conversion of glucose in methanol, respectively. The authors demonstrated that Al3+ ions play a vital role in the catalytic process by accelerating the rate-limiting step, inducing ring opening of the key intermediate, methyl-D-glucopyranoside (MDGP), to D-glucose dimethyl acetal, as shown in Fig. 9 . In another study, tin(II) silico-tungstate was prepared using Sn(II) exchanged Keggin heteropolyacids H4SiW12O40 and explored as a potential catalyst for the synthesis of EL [127]. The results showed a low yield (Table 4, entry 18) was obtained when using glucose as raw material. Experimental results showed that the low Brønsted Nas value (0.4 mEq/g) of Sn2SiW12O40 treated at 423 K did not efficiently isomerize glucose to fructose, thereby resulting in the low yield of EL. Moreover, the authors also considered that the presence of Lewis acid sites in the reported Sn2SiW12O40 catalyst (0.8 mEq/g) to be insufficient to drive the isomerization of glucose. Gupta et al. [128] founded the HPW4Mo10Ox catalyst with highly acidic (0.84 mmol/g) was suitable for EL synthesis from glucose under microwave irradiation, with a total glucose conversion, 84.95 % EL selectivity and 62.0 % EL yield (Table 4, entry 19). However, the authors prepared the HPW4Mo10O x -Cys catalyst, using L-cysteine ethyl ester hydrochloride as a binder, which more likely to generate HMF when using glucose as reaction substrate, giving only 5.4 % EL yield (Table 4, entry 20). Ayashi et al. [129] produced a series of phosphomolybdic acid (HPMo) catalysts supported on carbon mesoporous CMK-8 and CMK-3, respectively, and demonstrated that the optimum catalyst CMK-HPM-50 reached the maximum yield of BL and EL from glucose was 57 % and 64 % at 180 °C, respectively (Table 4, entries 21-22). Interestingly, a trifunctional polyoxometalate Cs10.6[H2.4GeNb13O41] catalyst, which included Brønsted acid sites, Lewis acid sites, and basic sites, was successfully synthesized and used for synthesis of ML from glucose [130]. As a result, a glucose conversion of 90.0 % and an ML yield of 61.5 % were obtained (Table 4, entry 23). The direct one-pot synthesis of EL from glucose was studied by Mulik et al. [131], who using the combination of Brønsted (H1Zr2PW12O40/H2Zr1PW12O40) and Lewis (Sn-Beta) acid catalyst (Table 4, entries 24-28). As reported, a 54 % yield of EL was obtained from 30 g/L of glucose under the reaction of 180 °C within 3 h using a mixture catalyst of H2Zr1PW12O40 and Sn-Beta in a weight ratio of 80:20. The aforementioned studies suggest that HPA catalysts demonstrate significant potential for the one-pot conversion of glucose to LEs. A key advantage is the ability to tailor their properties by incorporating Lewis acid metals (e.g., Ti, Zr, Al) to create bifunctional catalysts that facilitate the critical isomerization of glucose to fructose, thereby significantly enhancing LEs yields. In addition, some HPAs can form a pseudoliquid phase in polar solvents, greatly improving reactant access to active sites and thereby enabling high catalytic activity in the conversion of glucose. However, challenges such as solubility in polar media, low surface area, and the need for precise balance between Brønsted and Lewis acid sites must be addressed to fully realize their practical application. 3.5 Zeolite catalyst Zeolite molecular sieves are a kind of solid acid catalyst that have been widely used in the field of biomass conversion because of their unique catalytic properties, such as adjustable surface acidity and excellent shape selectivity. However, as a typical aluminosilicate zeolites, HZSM-5 gave a relatively low yield (Table 5 , entries 1-5) for in the one-opt conversion of glucose to LEs [91,132–134]. The steric hindrance of the rather bulky molecules in the medium pore channels of H-ZSM-5 was contributed to the main reason for the low yield. Notably, the H-Y zeolite could afford significant amounts of ML (Table 5, entries 6-9), because they process larger pore channels than H-ZSM-5 for the access of bulky molecules in glucose conversion [101,132,133,135]. In addition, the H-Y zeolite has an appropriate density of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites in high strength, which facilitate glucose-fructose isomerization and dehydration/rehydration reactions, respectively. It is noteworthy that H-Beta seems to be good catalyst for convert glucose into LEs, giving a relatively high LEs yields (Table 5, entries 10-11) [132]. Especially, a moderate EL yield of 48.3 % (Table 5, entry 12) was given over H-Beta catalyst when the glucose used as start substrate with addition of 1,3,5-trioxande [136]. Using only methanol and the Hβ−25 catalyst, yields of 53.9 % for the intermediate MG and 44.4 % for ML were obtained from glucose (Table 5, entry 13) [137]. Interestingly, the addition of dimethoxymethane as co-solvent significantly enhanced the yield of ML from glucose, increasing it from 44.4 % to 56.7 % (Table 5, entry 14) while reducing the yield of intermediate MG to only 0.8 %. It is suggested that a smaller proportion of ML occurs through the intermediate MG compared to the intermediate fructose. H-USY zeolite, which has proper B and L acidity, exhibits good catalytic activity in the conversion of glucose to ML and EL, respectively (Table 5, entries 15-17) [132,133,138]. It is worth noting that Xu et al. and Li et al. investigated the effect of solvent using ultrastable Y zeolite (USY) as a catalyst in a co-solvent system for the conversion of glucose [139]. They found that the etrahydrofuran (THF) as the co-solvent could reduced the adverse alcoholysis of EMF to EL, therefore, the main product is EMF (41.5 %) rather than EL (5.4 %) at 200 °C for 10 min (Table 5, entries 18-19). Much effort has been devoted to improving the catalytic performance of zeolite-based catalysts for the conversion of glucose to LEs. The acidity of the zeolite could be regulated by adjusting the Si/Al ratio during the preparation process. Saravanamurugan et al. [132] found that the H-USY (6) with Si/Al ratios of 6 gave 49 % and 41 % yield of ML and EL, respectively, which higher than those of H-USY (30) with Si/Al ratios of 30 (Table 5, entries 20-23). In addition, the H-USY (6) catalyst can be reused for at least five consecutive cycles without significant loss of catalytic activity. Zhou et al. [134] reported that the modified H-USY, after being treated with a nitric acid solution to remove the extra-framework Al species, efficiently catalyzes glucose to ML in 54 % yield at 160 °C (Table 5, entry 24). The results suggested that nitric acid with proper concentration can increase the mesoporosity and acidity of H-USY, promoting the formation of LEs. Metal doping is a feasible way to tune catalytic sites in inorganic materials. Metal-zeolite hybrids were prepared by impregnation (IP) or deposition-precipitation (DP) methods and applied to the conversion of glucose to ML in methanol [135]. The authors found that Zr deposited onto HY2.6 zeolite by IP method gave relatively lower ML yields compared with ZrY2.6 prepared by DP method (Table 5, entries 25-26). Moreover, it was also found that zirconia-zeolite hybrid ZrY6(0.5) with moderate zirconium content exhibited higher catalytic activity than ZrY6(1) and ZrY6(0.25), giving a high ML yield of 68 % at 180 °C for 3 h (Table 5, entries 27-29). Interestingly, compared with conventional heating (the yield of ML was 46 %) (Table 5, entry 30), microwave irradiation in this study using ZrY6(0.5) dramatically shortened the reaction time and significantly increased the ML yield [135]. Metal modify zeolites prepared by impregnation method on H–Y support could tuned the Lewis acid content, thereby influence the conversion of glucose into LEs. Very recently, Zhang et al. synthesized a series of bifunctional catalysts (xZr-HY) with Lewis and Brønsted acid sites via a simple impregnation method, and used for the conversion of glucose to ML and LA [140]. The reaction was performed at 200 °C for 2.5 h, and the yield of ML reached 39.2 % (Table 5, entries 31). In addition, it was observed that both Sn/Y(Si/Al=15) and Zr/Y(Si/Al=15) catalysts exhibited higher EL yields than that of H/Y(Si/Al=15), while the yield for Cr/Y(Si/Al=15) was lower than that of H/Y(Si/Al=15) (Table 5, entries 32-34) [141]. However, the conversion of glucose to ML over M-Beta zeolites (an L acid catalyst), such as Zr-Beta-h, Ti-Beta-h, Ce-Beta-p, Sn-Beta-h, Sn-Beta-p, resulting in the relatively low yield of ML (0–4 %) (Table entries 35-42) [133]. Aho et al. [142] investigated various metal-modified Beta zeolites as catalysts for the conversion of glucose to ML. It was found that modification with copper (Cu-H-Beta-25) can significantly enhance catalytic selectivity, giving a ML yield of 92.8 % (Table 5, entry 43) at 180 °C for 24 h under argon atmosphere. It presumed that the intermediate methyl glucoside was eventually transformed to ML (Fig. 10 ). Yang et al. [143] syntheszied mesoporous bifunctional Sn-Al-β zeolite via post-synthesis method. The synergistic effects of the increase of L acidity by introduction of tin and the enhancement of mesoporosity are favorable for the production of ML from glucose. Sn-Al-β catalyst exhibited high catalytic activity and gave 49 % yield of ML (Table 5, entry 44) at 180 °C for 5 h, which is higher or comparable with the catalyst of H2SO4. After the reaction, the Sn-Al-β zeolite was filtered and calcined in air at 550 °C for reuse, and it still maintained good catalytic activity after four cycles. Analogously, Li et al. [144] mentioned the Sn-Al-β zeolite exhibited superior in catalytic activity and selectivity to ML from glucose as compared to Sn-β (containing only Lewis acid sites), Al-β (containing only Brønsted acid sites) and the physically mixed sample of Sn-β and Al-β (Table 5, entries 40-41, 45-46). It is noteworthy to point out three Brønsted acid sites with different acidic strength were distinguished by 13C NMR of 2-13C-acetone probe molecule. One of these acid sites was close to being a “super acid”, most likely due to the synergistic effect between the spatially adjacent Brønsted and Lewis acid sites, which enhance the reaction rate of fructose dehydration to form HMF, thereby increasing the competitive advantage for the reaction pathway to form ML while suppressing the reaction pathway for MLA formation (Fig. 11 ). Another interesting catalyst, Sn-Al-USY, was fabricated via simple post-synthetic methods and directly affords a high EL yield (82.4 %) (Table 5, entry 47) from glucose [145]. It was found that Sn-, Ti-, or Zr-Beta zeolite combined with Amberlyst-15 (a pure B acid) as catalyst, the yields of ML significantly increased as compared to using Sn-, Ti-, or Zr-Beta zeolite alone (Table 5, entries 48-52) [133]. Zhang et al. [146] compared the catalytic performance of Sn-Beta, p-toluenesulfonic acid (PTSA), and the combined Sn-Beta + PTSA system for the one-pot conversion of glucose into ML. It was demonstrated that the combination of Sn-Beta and PTSA gave the highest yield of ML(68.3 %) (Table 5, entry 53) under optimal conditions. The combination of H-USY with SnO2 showed higher EL yield than the combination with other Lewis acidic catalysts, such as TiO2, ZrO2 and Sn-beta (Table 5, entries 54-57), was found by Heda et al. [138]. The SnO2 provides strong Lewis acid sites that efficiently facilitates the conversion of glucosides to fructosides via isomerization reaction, leading to the formation of EL. Moreover, the yield of EL can be further improved by optimizing key factors such as the mass ratio of H-USY to SnO2, catalyst dosage, temperature, glucose concentration, and reaction time. A maximum EL yield of 81 % (Table 5, entry 58) was obtained at 180 °C for 3 h. However, the higher catalyst dosage in catalytic system was used. Chang and co-workers [147] reported that the combination of extremely low sulfuric acid (0.1 %) and USY can be used as an effective catalytic system for one-pot production of EL from glucose, resulting in 51.5 % EL yield (Table 5, entry 59). Similarly, the combination of carbon–silica composite (C/Si-SO3H) and zirconium modified ultrastable Y zeolite (Zr/USY) were utilized in the conversion of glucose to EL, producing 65.8 % EL yield (Table 5, entry 60) at 180 °C for 12 h [148]. Very recently, grafting propyl sulfonic acid on Y zeolite (HY-Pr-SO3H) was prepared by a modified post-synthesis method [141]. As expected, the HY-Pr-SO3H exhibited relatively good catalytic activity compared to HY, and an EL yield of 25.2 % was achieved (Table 5, entry 61). When HY-Pr-SO3H combined with SnO2, with strong Brønsted and Lewis acidity, demonstrated to be effective for conversion glucose into EL, resulting in a yield of 57.6 % EL under optimal conditions (Table 5, entries 62-64). However, it is worth noting that the reaction conditions were under high pressure, specifically 2 MPa of N2. The above-mentioned studies have suggested zeolite-based catalysts such as H-Y and H-USY possess larger pore architectures that mitigate diffusion limitations for bulky intermediates in the glucose conversion process. Their acidity can be finely tuned by adjusting the Si/Al ratio or via post synthetic modifications. A major advantage is their capacity to form bifunctional catalysts through the incorporation of Lewis acid metals (e.g., Sn, Zr), which facilitate the critical isomerization of glucose to fructose, significantly enhancing overall LE yields. Additionally, zeolites typically demonstrate good thermal stability and reusability. Zeolite-based catalysts, when physically combined with other catalysts (e.g., SnO2, Amberlyst-15), can form a balanced Brønsted/Lewis acid system, leading to improved catalytic performance. However, the inherent microporous structure of zeolite-based catalysts should not be ignored, since it can cause mass transfer restrictions and steric hindrance. 3.6 Silica-based catalyst Metal-modified mesoporous catalyst such as Al-MCM-41, Al-SBA-15, and Sn-SBA-15 has a larger pore diameter than that of zeolite microporous materials. However, they gave low yields of EL and ML (Table 6 , entries 1-3) because the mesoporous structures could led to the accumulate of intermediate products such as 5-MMF and 5-EMF, which promote humins formation [141,149]. In addition, the catalyst SO3H-SBA-15-D produced only a trace amount of EL from glucose (Table 6, entry 4), indicating that the sulfonic acid groups did not facilitate the required isomerization of glucose to fructose for EL formation. As a result, the main product was ethyl-D-glucopyranoside in 80 % yield [150]. Jorge et al. [151] compared sulfonated silica materials, such as MCM-41-SA, FDU-12-SA, SBA-15-SA, and KCC-1-SA catalysts for upgrading glucose to EL, and displayed a lower activities, yielding EL in the range of 4 % to 19 % (Table 6, entries 5-8). In contrast, sulfonated dendritic mesoporous silica nanospheres, named DMSi-SA, showed good catalytic performance, achieving an EL yield of 62 % (Table 6, entry 9). The hierarchical pore system, high surface area and pore diameter, and elevated amount of thiol and sulfonic acid groups were considered as the combination of factors for high activity in converting glucose to EL. However, it was noted that the catalytic stability of DMSi-SA decreased significantly after the second cycle, which was probably related to the deactivation of the Lewis acid sites. Zhang et al. [90] prepared KCC-1/Al-SO3H catalyst using fibrous nanoporous silica particles (KCC-1/Al) as carriers. An EL yield of 42.5 % (Table 6, entry 10) was obtained from glucose in a mixture of ethanol and toluene at 200 °C for 6 h over KCC-1/Al-SO3H catalyst that contained abundant Lewis-Brønsted acid sites. Three modified porous silica solid acid catalysts such as SO3H-Al/Silica, SO3H-Al-Zr/Silica, and SO3H-Zr/Silica, were prepared and employed for the synthesis of EL from glucose, achieving satisfactory yields (Table 6, entry 11-13) [152]. Among these catalysts, SO3H-Al/Silica processes the highest total acid amount (3.55 mmol/g), a high B/L ratio, a relatively large specific surface area and pore volume, and a small pore size, All of which directly affect the EL yield. A 47.9 % yield of EL was achieved over SO3H-Al/Silica catalyst at 180 °C after 12 h.However, improving the thermal stability of catalysts and reducing the loss of acidic sites remain a significant challenge. Babaei et al. [153] reported that bimetallic Zr/Al catalysts (Zr/Al(2)-SB) immobilized on SBA-15 mesoporous silica was used for direct conversion glucose into BL, achieving 63.4 % BL yield (Table 6, entry 14) under the conditions of 170 °C for 5 h. Moreover, the catalyst can be recovered at least four runs without a noticeable decrease in BL yield. Recently, Mohammadbagheri et al. [154] compared two types of dendritic fibrous nanosilica, one prepared by the ultrasonic method (DFNSU) and the other by the hydrothermal method (DFNSH), for loading of different amount of zinc and then applied the resulting materials to the direct production of hexyl levulinate HL from glucose.The results demonstrated that the maximum yield (55.2 %) (Table 6, entry 15) of HL was obtained directly using glucose as starting substrate in the presence of 40Zn/DFNSu catalyst at 200 °C for 5 h. In parallel, the catalytic performance of Zn/DFNSH catalysts with different zinc values were compared, and the highest HL yield of 59.2 % (Table 6, entry 16) was achieved over the 40Zn/DFNSH catalyst. Furthermore, the 40Zn/DFNSu catalyst was featured by very good reusability with no change in glucose conversion and an insignificant reduction (9 %) in HL yield after four cycles. Although a possible pathway for the formation of HL was proposed (Fig. 12 ), the mechanisms involved were not comprehensively elucidated in this study. From the above, it is clear that silica-based catalysts like sulfonated dendritic silica (DMSi-SA) or metal-functionalized catalysts (e.g., 40Zn/DFNS) have achieved impressive EL yields of up to 62–63 %, benefiting from hierarchical porosity, high surface area, and balanced acidity. Nevertheless, silica-based catalysts still face significant challenges, including low activity for the critical glucose-to-fructose isomerization, acidic site leaching, poor hydrothermal stability and rapid deactivation, which remain major obstacles to their practical application. 3.7 Sulfonated carbon-based catalyst Carbon materials functionalized with SO3H groups represent a class of heterogeneous solid acid catalysts that have rapidly developed and garnered increasing attention due to their abundance, environmentally friendly origin, simple synthesis, and outstanding performance. Bosilj et al. [93] studied one-pot conversion of glucose to EL over an acid-functionalised hydrothermal catalyst derived from glucose (HTC-400-S) in a stainless-steel high pressure autoclave. In co-solvent of ethanol and glycerol (GLY) at 200 °C for 6 h, the EL yield of 37 % was obtained. The authors found the yield of EL obtained in the mixed solvents such as γ-valerolactone (GVL) or GLY with EtOH was higher than that with EtOH alone (Table 7 , entries 1-3). It was suggested that GVL and GLY play important roles in promoting the conversion of glucose to EL. Very recently, Dowaki et al. [155] prepared a series of functionalized biochars catalyst, obtained by treating lignin-derived biochar with aluminum diacetate and thiomalic acid, and evaluated their catalytic performance for glucose transformation. The characterization results demonstrated that the Lewis and Brønsted acid sites of the catalyst could be simply tuned by varying the ratio of aluminum diacetate (x) to thiomalic acid (y) during ball-milling. The Al:S-Lig (2.7:1.3) biochar catalyst suppressed EMF ring-opening, yielding 32.6 % EMF. In contrast, the maximum EL yield of 69 % (Table 7, entry 4) was obtained from glucose at 150 °C for 6 h with the Al:S-Lig (2:2) biochar catalyst, which promoted the EMF ring-opening (Fig. 13 ). The Al3+ acts as Lewis acid sites that interact with the carbonyl group on glucose, allowing effective isomerization of glucose into fructose, followed by dehydration to HMF. EMF forms by etherification that is promoted with ethanol activated by Brønsted acid. Then, EMF undergoes ring-opening to form EL. Furthermore, it was observed that the addition of ethyl acetate and THF suppressed the ring-opening of EMF, thereby decreasing the formation of EL. Babaei et al. [156] synthesized the two sulfonated CMK-3 catalysts, CMK-SOM (prepared with mercaptopropyltriethoxy silane) and CMK-SOS (prepared with 1, 4-sultone), each bearing a distinct sulfonic acid group, and evaluated their performance for BL production from glucose. As a result, the catalytic performance of CMK-SOM was higher than that of CMK-SOS, and a satisfactory BL yield of 70.4 % was reached at 190 for 5 h (Table 7, entries 5-7). Moreover, the authors proved that the catalyst could be reused for at least five cycles without significant loss of activity. Guo et al. [157] employed a bifunctional carbon Ni/NiO nanofiber catalyst, which was prepared via solvothermal carbonization of 5-sulfosalicylic acid/NiSO4, for the transformation of glucose to EL, obtaining the negligible EL yield (<7 %) (Table 7, entry 8). This study demonstrated that glucose undergoes ethanolysis to form ethyl-D-glycopyranoside rather than isomerizing into fructose. The iron doped sulfonated carbon cryogel catalyst (UCC-S-Fe) was developed by Zainol et al. [158], who found the yield of EL was increased with the rising reaction temperature and glucose concentration. An EL yield of 39.6 mol % (Table 7, entry 9) was achieved at a glucose-to-catalyst ratio of 1: 5 g/g at 200 °C for 6 h. Similarly, Zhang et al. [159] observed a 19.1 % yield of ML (Table 7, entry 10) in the conversion of glucose in an ethanol medium over FeCl3 modified carbon catalyst (AC-Fe-SO3H). Very recently, the activated carbon (AC) precursor was modified via sulfonation and impregnated with iron (Fe), copper (Cu) and cobalt (Co) metals [160]. Among synthesized catalysts, AC-S-Cu exhibited the highest catalytic activity for transforming glucose into ML and EL, achieving the corresponding yields of 14.7 % and 15.0 %, respectively (Table 7, entries 11-15). The coexistence of Brønsted and Lewis acidic sites with significant Brønsted acidity, higher thermal stability with minimum weight loss up to 200 °C (<2 wt %), improved morphology, and larger surface area (928 m2/g) contributed to higher catalytic activity of AC-S-Cu compared to other metal-sulfonated activated carbons. In addition, Asmadi’s research group [161] reported that zinc modified sulfonated carbon (UFCS-Zn), which was prepared by sulfonation and Zn impregnation of urea-furfural carbon cryogel (UFC), could also achieve a 27.4 mol % EL yield (Table 7, entry 16) from glucose at 180 °C for 6 h. Zainol et al. [162] also explored the synthesis of EL from glucose using sulfonated carbon cryogel with zinc (SCC-Zn) catalyst. A 19.6 mol % yield of EL (Table 7, entry 17) was obtained at 180 °C for 6 h with 0.15 g catalyst loading and 0.4 g of glucose feed. Further improvement, including detailed parameters optimization could be required to increase the EL yield. In another remarkable example, Fan et al. [163] prepared a series of bifunctional solid acid catalysts via a high temperature carbonization (200-400 °C), hydrothermal sulfonation and metal impregnation method, using cellulose as the carbon source (Table 7, entries 18-22). The results showed that the catalyst 300-AC-Cr-SO3H exhibited good catalytic performance for the directional conversion of glucose into ML and LA, affording 99.6 % glucose conversion. It was suggested that the metal Cr in the catalyst provides L acid sites, which facilitates the isomerization of glucose to fructose, while the -SO3H group provides B acid sites, which promote the subsequent conversion of glucose into EL and LA in methanol. The authors claimed that the combination of large pore size, suitable specific surface area, and appropriate B- and L-acid density was contributed to the good catalytic performance of 300-AC-Cr-SO3H. Furthermore, the catalyst maintained good catalytic activity after three cycles. Sulfonated carbon-based catalysts represent a highly promising class of solid acid catalysts such as CMK-SOM and Al:S-Lig functionalized biochar for the one-pot conversion of glucose to LEs. Furthermore, sulfonated carbon-based catalyst precursors are highly versatile, ranging from biomass (e.g., lignin, cellulose) to synthetic mesoporous carbons, thus enabling the tailored design of sulfonated carbon-based catalysts with optimized metal-acid synergy, pore structure, and surface functionality. Noteworthy, the adsorption of humins on the catalyst surface and the leaching of sulfonic groups during the catalytic process lead to a decrease in acidity, which limits the employment of sulfonated carbon-based catalysts for the conversion of glucose to LEs. 3.8 Modified montmorillonite catalyst Montmorillonite (MMT) is a typical natural clay that is abundant, has a large surface area and strong cation-exchange ability, and therefore shows greatly potential as a heterogeneous catalyst in various reactions [164]. Various metal ion (Al3+, Cu2+, Cr3+, In3+, Er3+, and La3+)-exchanged MMT catalysts were fabricated by an ion exchange method, and their catalytic performance was compared for the conversion of glucose into ML (Table 8 , entries 1-6) [165]. Among these metal ion-exchanged MMT catalysts, Al3+-exchanged MMT was believed to the best catalytic because of presence of a large number of acid sites (0.244 mmol/g) and a good ratio of Brønsted to Lewis acid sites (0.82) on the catalyst, obtaining 60.7 % yield of ML at 220 °C under 2 MPa N2 for 6 h. Although Cu2+-exchanged MMT exhibited good catalytic activity at 220 °C, giving a 58.7 % yield of ML, the Cu2+ species in Cu2+-exchanged MMT were gradually reduced to Cu0 by hot methanol, which lead to the catalyst deactivation. In addition, Cr3+-exchanged MMT possesses the largest amount of acid sites (0.311 mmol/g), however, it only gave a moderate ML yield, indicating that the ratio of Brønsted to Lewis acid sites is crucial in the muti-step conversion of glucose. Liu et al. [166] further prepared tin-exchanged MMT catalysts using an ion exchange method to catalyze glucose into ML in methanol. The synergistic effects of a large amount of acidic sites and a balanced amount of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst provided a high ML yield of 59.7 % (Table 8, entry 7) under the conditions of conversion of 0.3 g glucose in 24 g methanol over 0.15 g catalyst at 220 °C under 2 MPa N2 for 6 h. More importantly, it was verified that the ML yield remained at 56.1 % (Table 8, entry 8) when 0.5 g of water was added to the reaction system, implying that the catalyst was stable. It was observed that the yield of ML decreased gradually from 51.0 % to 23.8 % (Table 8, entries 9-11) at the reaction temperature of 220 °C when the calcined tin-exchanged MMT catalyst was used, corresponding to an increase in calcination temperature from 300 to 500 °C. A series of sulfated MMT(SO4 2-/MMT) catalysts, prepared with H2SO4 after calcination, were utilized in the conversion of glucose into ML [102]. Among these catalysts, a highly efficient catalyst 20-SO4 2-/MMT produced 48 mol % yield of ML at 200 °C for 4 h (Table 8, entries 12-15). It is worth noting that enhancing the stability of the SO4 2-/MMT catalyst is essential, since the reused catalyst (calcined at 500 °C after each run) yielded only 21 % of EL, likely due to partial sulfur leaching from the catalyst. 3.9 SO4 2-/metal oxides catalyst A serious of sulfonated single metal oxides, such as SO4 2-/SnO2 [167], SO4 2-/Al2O3 [168], SO4 2-/TiO2 [169], SO4 2-/ZrO2 [170], have been investigated for one-pot convert glucose into LEs, affording LEs yields ranging from 9.8 to 44.6 % (Table 9 , entries 1-9). For example, the ordered mesoporous SO4 2-/Al2O3 were prepared by evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) method, followed by sulphonation, and showed the low EL yield (28.5 %) (Table 9, entry 2) from glucose [168]. Peng et al. [171] proved that the SO4 2-/TiO2 catalyst used as the potential catalyst with high activity and remarkably selectivity for conversion of glucose into LEs after various solid acids including ZSM-5(25), ZSM-5(36), NaY, H-mordenite, Zr3(PO4)4, SO4 2-/ZrO2, and TiO2 were compared under the same conditions. Although a 33.2 % yield of ML (Table 9, entry 4) was achieved at 200 °C for 2 h, the partial loss of sulfur in the catalyst, which attributed to the deactivation of catalyst, could not to be disregard. The mesoporous sulfated TiO2–ZrO2 catalyst, prepared by a single-step coprecipitation method using titanium oxysulfate–sulfuric acid complex as a precursor of both titanium and sulfate ions, were showed a moderate ML yield (23 %) (Table 9, entry 10) from glucose [172]. Peng et al. [173] also observed that SO4 2-/ZrO2 was an optimized catalyst which gave above 30 % ML yield (Table 9, entry 11) at 200 °C for 3 h with catalyst dosage of 2.5 wt %. It was found that the sulfated binary metal oxides, SO4 2-/ZrO2-Al2O3, showed lower catalytic activity than sulfated individual metal oxides. Similar phenomena were also observed for the SO4 2-/ZrO2-TiO2 catalyst [169]. In this study, the catalytic activity of SO4 2-/TiO2 higher than SO4 2-/ZrO2-TiO2 catalyst with Zr/Ti molar ratio of 3/1 and calcined at 450 °C (Table 9, entry 12), which process the highest surface area and largest acid site amount, suggesting that the moderate acid sites were responsible for the formation of ML. More interestingly, Zhang et al. successfully prepared the bimetallic composite solid superacid SO4 2-/ZrO2@Al2O3 using the zirconium-based UiO-66 as a precursor and directly converted glucose into EL in ethanol in a yield of 37.5 mol % (Table 9, entry 14) after 5 h at 200 °C [170]. The excellent catalytic performance of SO4 2-/ZrO2@Al2O3-3 M could be attributed to its high acid density, particularly the density of B acid sites, high BET specific surface area (330 m2/g), and unique nanostructure. The bi-functional catalyst SO4 2-/TiO2-La2O3 coating Fe3O4 contains both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites and showed high catalytic activity for the conversion of glucose into ML, giving a satisfactory ML yield of 92.6 % (Table 9, entry 15) [174]. It is worth noting that the quaternary metal oxides-based catalyst Zr-Sn-Fe-Al-O-S with 1.11 mmol/g strong acidic sites and a total acidity of 1.50 mmol/g gave a relatively low yield of EL (0.8 %)(Table 9, entry 16) from glucose in pure ethanol after 20 h. When DMSO and ethanol were used as co-solvents, the EL yield improves to 8.6 % (Table 9, entry 17) within12 h, indicating DMSO as a better co-solvent for the formation of EL [175]. Conformal sulphated zirconia monolayers throughout an SBA-15 was prepared through a simple wet chemical grafting/hydrolysis protocol, and exhibits good performance in the one-pot conversion of glucose to ML and EL (Table 9, entries 18-19) under mild conditions [176]. It was proved that the isomerization of ethyl glucoside to ethyl fructoside was more slower than the subsequent dehydration of ethyl fructoside to HMF. In addition, grafted SZ/SBA-15 combined with ZrO2 enhanced the isomerization of ethyl glucoside to ethyl fructoside step, raising the net EL yield to 30.7 % (Table 9, entry 20). The transformation of glucose to ML was studied over SO4 2-/ZrO2 combined with Sn-Beta as catalysts [133]. The synergistic effect of solid Brønsted (B) acid from SO4 2-/ZrO2 and solid Lewis (L) acid from SO4 2-/ZrO2 and Sn-Beta was observed, affording a 62 % ML yield (Table 9, entry 21) from glucose at 170 °C after 24 h. The possible reaction pathways for the catalytic conversion of glucose were proposed and is illustrated in Fig. 14 . It was suggested that the dehydration of fructose to HMF was the rate determining step for the formation of ML from glucose. As demonstrated in this study, the combined catalyst system exhibited satisfactory reusability without a significant change in the yield of ML over five recycles. A series of ordered mesoporous sulfonic acid functionalized ZrO2/organosilica catalysts (SO4 2-/ZrO2-PMO-SO3H) possessing tunable Brønsted and Lewis acid site distributions were designed and successfully prepared by a P123-directed sol-gel co-condensation route, followed by ClSO3H functionalization [177]. Thanks to the considerably high both Brønsted and Lewis acid site density, optimal Brønsted/Lewis molar ratio (0.99), and excellent porosity properties, the highest EL yield (42.3 %) was obtained over SO4 2-/ZrO2-PMO-SO3H1.0 (Table 9, entries 22-25). The spent catalyst exhibited superb reusability after three recycles, owing to the strong covalent bonding between double B acid sites and the ZrO2-PMO framework. Additionally, the surface hydrophobicity of the catalysts could effectively avoid its deactivation. Nevertheless, a low EL yield was obtained under the same reaction conditions using SO4 2-/Nb2O5-PMO-SO3H1.0 and SO4 2-/TiO2-PMO-SO3H1.0 (Table 9, entries 26-27), which could be due to their lower BET surface area and acid densities. Sulfated metal oxides possess both Lewis and strong Brønsted acidities, which is crucial for the targeted conversion of glucose into LEs. Although some catalysts have achieved promising results, the catalytic efficiency is highly sensitive to metal composition, sulfate loading, and thermal treatment methods. 3.10 Other sulfonic acid functionalized catalysts Amberlyst-15 is a typical strong Brønsted acid catalyst. Nevertheless, it exhibited only poor or moderate performance in the catalytic conversion of glucose to LEs (Table 10 , entries 1-4) [91,133,134]. Although the yield of ML could reach 52.5 % (Table 10, entry 5) when glucose was used as a reactant with the Amberlyst-70 catalyst [178], the stability of Amberlyst resins remains a major constraint for their application in alcoholic media. Gu et al. reported that hyper-cross-linked organic polymer based carbonaceous materials, which have high surface areas and strong Brϕnsted acidity, were prepared using bischloromethyl monomers (α, α′ -dichloro-p-xylene and 4,4′ -bis(chloromethyl)-1,1′ -biphenyl) as the precursors [179]. Among these materials, the optimal catalyst HDS-3.6 was applied as a solid acid for the direct transformation of glucose into EL, and an EL yield of 25 % (Table 10, entry 6) was achieved at 170 °C after 8 h. The catalytic system Sn/ZrP-SO3H contains both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites was developed and utilized for EL production [180]. The yield of EL obtained was 49.3 % (Table 10, entry 7), when glucose was used as the starting material and subjected to 170 °C for 10 h. An ultra-high performance fiber catalyst (PPSF-SO3H), which was conveniently prepared from commercially available polyphenylene sulfide fiber by sulfonation, exhibited good catalytic activity for the glucose into ML [181]. It was observed that the EL yield increased from 49 % over PPSF-SO3H to 62.5 % over the combination of PPSF-SO3H and SnCl4 (Table 10, entries 8-9). Yu et al. [182] founded that the yields of EL and ML were 60 % and 61 % (Table 10, entries 10-11) at 160 °C over chlorinated sulfonated hyperbranched poly(arylene oxindole)s (5-Cl-SHPAO) after 12 h and 8 h, respectively. Recently, Zhang et al. [183] investigated cucurbit[6]uril-sulfate (Q[6]-sulfate) as the catalyst for the production of EL from glucose. A yield of 97.1 % EL (Table 10, entry 12) after 10 h at 180 °C was obtained. The control experiments further demonstrated that at the higher temperature of 180 °C was favorable for the isomerization of glucose into furctose and the isomerization of ethyl glucoside to ethyl fructoside. In recent years, some organic–inorganic hybrid acid catalysts have been developed and are also expected to be further applied in the catalytic conversion of glucose [184]. Future development will likely focus on sulfonic acid-functionalized catalysts that combine strong acidity, a balanced ratio of Brønsted to Lewis acid sites, high surface area, low cost, and operational simplicity. 4 Technical challenges Glucose, as the starting substrate, may undergo various reaction pathways for the production of LEs in different catalytic systems. Meanwhile, the resulting distribution of intermediates and by-products is highly dependent on the specific catalytic process employed. Although many studies have documented the formation of humins and proposed humins are derived from the substances, the chemical structure of humins has still not been determined among the various reaction pathways. It is essential to employ powerful characterization techniques to elucidate the formation of by-products during the multi-steps conversion of glucose. The combination of experimental validation and theoretical calculation will undoubtedly provide valuable insights into the selective catalytic pathways for the conversion of glucose into LEs. Therefore, it is crucial to identify the structures of by-products, especially humins, which helps to clarify the reaction pathways and thereby contributes to the reduction of by-products in the conversion process and increases the selectivity of LEs. Moreover, since humins adsorbed on the catalyst surface lead to deactivation, developing effective regeneration protocols, such as calcination or solvent washing, is of practical importance. The choice of catalyst significantly affects the catalytic pathway of glucose, thereby influencing both the glucose conversion rate and the yield of LEs. Homogeneous catalysis often faces significant challenges in achieving both high yields and catalyst recyclability, while also ensuring the feasibility of scale-up protocols. Some homogeneous catalysis still faces issues such as corrosion, contamination, and poor recyclability, even when using a low catalyst concentrations. The pursuit of efficient, economical, and green pathways for the direct alcoholysis of glucose into LEs is an ongoing endeavor. Solid acid catalysts, which are easy to separate from products, reusable, and stable, have received widespread attention. Sulfonic acid functionalized catalysts possess high acidity, however, a low yield of LEs was obtained due to the presence of only Brønsted acidity. It is noteworthy that the one-pot conversion process of glucose into LEs involves a combination of Lewis and Brønsted acidity. In contrast to mono-functional solid catalysts, multi-functional heterogeneous catalysts can not only enhance the selectivity of the target products via tandem reactions, but also integrate the catalytic transformation and product/catalyst recovery in a simple one-pot process [185]. In particular, the total amount of acid sites and the ratio of Lewis and Brønsted acidity are appropriate, which is crucial for the selective conversion of glucose to LEs. Deposition, impregnation, and post-synthesis grafting methods are widely used for introducing additional acid sites in catalyst preparation. The properties of the carrier, along with the interactions between the catalytic sites and the carrier, significantly influence the catalyst activity. Carriers with appropriately positioned Lewis or Brønsted acid sites and suitable acid strength tend to enhance the conversion of glucose more effectively. Given the diverse interactions between different carriers and substrates, such as the adsorption of substrates, the formation of intermediate, and the accumulation of humins that can occupy active sites, the development of suitable carriers, such as metal organic frameworks, is of great significance. Moreover, doped and supported catalyst may cause several issues, such as mass-transfer limitations, leaching/deactivation of active sites, and increased fabrication costs, which need to be carefully managed to ensure both economic viability and catalytic efficiency. Furthermore, the yield of LEs is influenced by various factors related to the structure of the catalyst, such as surface area and pore structure, in addition to the amount and types of acidity. It is worth noting that the spatial distribution of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst is also crucial for the continuous transformation of intermediate products and the formation of by-products during the selective conversion of glucose into LEs. The development of effective and stability solid multi-functional acid catalysts, therefore, has become one of the most attractive research areas for the direct synthesis of LEs from glucose. Therefore, the rational design and preparing of catalyst requires careful consideration of a wide range of parameters, including catalyst acid amount and strength, the ratio of Lewis to Brønsted acid sites, surface area, chemical and thermal stability, and preparation costs. The conversion of glucose and the yield of LEs are influenced by various reaction factors, such as the concentration of glucose, reaction temperature, reaction time, pressure, heating method, solvents, and so on. Optimizing the reaction conditions for the one-pot conversion of glucose is necessary for high activity and yield. The single-factor experimental method, in which only one parameter is changed while others are kept at a constant level, is often chosen for the one-pot conversion of glucose. However, its major disadvantage is that it does not account for the interactive effects among the variables studied. Response surface methodology is one of the most relevant multivariate techniques that can be used to optimize the levels of various variables to achieve optimal system performance [186]. Moreover, the machine learning approach holds great promise in optimizing the one-pot conversion of glucose processes and will be further explored in the future. Besides, it is also expected to play a significant role in improving catalytic technologies and designing new catalytic materials. It was observed that only limited attention has been paid to the reaction scale, as many experiments typically start from 1–10 mmol of glucose, which is far from the scale required for large-scale production. Additionally, it is suggested that the glucose conversion is best conducted within a temperature range of 140–170 °C to achieve high LEs yields. Microwave heating method has the advantages of fast heating speed, internal temperature equalization, saving time, reducing cycle and mild reaction conditions. As expected, higher yields of LEs appears to be achieved from glucose using the microwave heating method, and this approach could be further explored in future research. The choice of reaction co-solvent is another crucial factor that significantly influences the catalytic reaction pathways, thereby influencing the selectivity of LEs. Methanol and ethanol are commonly employed as reaction solvents when glucose was used as the substrate, due to their convenience and the lower formation of by-products. Compared with the single alcohol reaction system, an appropriate co-solvent system generally can improve glucose conversion efficiency and LEs selectivity. The amount of co-solvent also needs to be rationally controlled in order not to reduce the yield of the target product. The co-solvent effects on catalytic reaction pathways for glucose requires further investigation. It is worth noting that adding water as a co-solvent to the catalytic reaction system is of great importance. It appears that more Brønsted and Lewis acid sites can be activated, thereby enhancing/maintaining reaction activity and the selectivity of LEs. However, the stability of catalytic sites in water under the corresponding reaction conditions is worth considering. Continuously exploring relatively mild conditions for the one-pot conversion of glucose into LEs will be a valuable area for future research. 5 Conclusion Biomass-derived LEs are vital platform molecules that have various applications, especially as promising bio-based transportation fuels. The direct synthesis of LEs from glucose has been widely studied. Over the last decade, various catalysts, such as inorganic acid, metal salts, ionic liquids, heteropolyacid, zeolite, silcia-based catalysts, sulfonated carbon catalysts, modified montmorillonite, sulfonate metal oxides, and other sulfonic acid functionalized catalysts have been successfully applied in this process. Generally, heterogeneous catalysts with high specific surface area, suitable pore size and tunable acid Brønsted and Lewis acid sites are preferred. Although the direct transformation of glucose into LEs has been successfully achieved, several practical challenges remain, including the need for higher yields, lower costs, simpler operation, and more sustainable processes. The rational design of catalysts and the optimization of catalytic processes are need to further improve the selectivity and yield of LEs. Also, the industrial scale-up of glucose conversion to LEs is still in its infancy and necessitates considerable further research and development. coredata.dc:description: Biomass resource has attracted extensive attention owing to abundance and potential for producing various high value-added chemicals and biofuels. Levulinate ester (LEs) are considered as one of the most attractive and potential energy compounds due to their excellent fuel additive/blending properties, as well as their broad applications in our daily life. LEs can be efficiently synthesized through the catalytic valorization of biomass-derived glucose via alcoholysis reactions. This review provides an overview of the most recent and promising advances in the one-pot production of LEs from glucose in the presence of acid catalysts. The plausible catalytic routes for preparation of LEs from glucose are analyzed. The development of different homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts used in this process is reviewed and compared. In this review, the combination of Brønsted and Lewis acid sites in an appropriate ratio is promising for effectively converting glucose into LEs. Moreover, future prospects, including opportunities and current challenges for the sustainable production of LEs from glucose, also be emphasized.
